title: McDonald's agrees to pay €1.25bn to settle French tax dispute
text:
McDonald's has agreed to pay €1.25bn to settle a dispute with French authorities over claims the fast-food chain diverted income abroad to cut its tax bill.

The settlement comes after a probe by France's anti-corruption and tax fraud prosecutors into a complaint originally made by employees that McDonald's had diverted income to a foreign jurisdiction to pay lower taxes between 2009 and 2020.

The finance ministry said on Thursday that it was the largest such settlement to date.

A McDonald's subsidiary in Luxembourg, MCD Luxembourg Real Estate, was part of the settlement, France's financial prosecutor said.

France, which borders the tiny grand duchy, has long been one of the company's largest markets outside the US.

The dispute centred on the abusive practice of royalties — transfer payments — between the French subsidiary and other parts of the group located abroad, the finance ministry said.

The settlement comes as France and other OECD governments seek to enforce a global minimum corporate rate to reduce tax avoidance by multinational companies.

Such companies have often paid minimal tax in some of their big markets by booking profits in low-tax jurisdictions such as Ireland and Luxembourg.

The McDonald's settlement includes a fine of about €508mn and tax paybacks and penalties of €609mn.

The amount is among the highest obtained through the French Public Interest Legal Convention, a mechanism set up in 2016 to allow companies to settle corruption and tax probes through fines.

McDonald's told French media that it had reached a deal without admission of guilt and would now “do everything possible to comply with the laws”. The company added that it had paid more than €2.2bn in corporate income tax in France and created almost 25,000 jobs during the 11 years in question.

The initial McDonald's probe, which started in 2016, was followed by a police raid at the company's French headquarters. The company denied any wrongdoing at the time.

Among previous tax settlements between multinationals and the French authorities, Google settled for almost €1bn in 2019 and Amazon for an undisclosed sum after the authorities demanded €200mn in 2018.

Other settlements — for example, the €2.1bn fine paid by Airbus in 2020 over aircraft and satellite sales in international markets — were to end investigations into corruption.

Additional reporting by Victor Mallet in Paris
